I’ve played this entirely on a Steam Deck.

If you wish there was another Morrowind, Oblivion, or Skyrim, then this is probably the closest thing you can get.

It seems a bit more Oblivion-ish because it isn’t quite as overdone as Skyrim, and it’s also a bit more “old school” in the sense of not being too easy and dumbed down to attract a larger audience.

Technical implementation: I didn’t really have any performance problems but I was using a steam deck which is hardware the game is specifically targeted for. The only FPS problem happens when you summon 3-5 wolves. It seems like a problem specifically with wolves for some reason. Other people sometimes have problems but these are usually solvable by reducing 2 graphics settings like vegetation quality. The game is built using Unity but you can’t really tell when playing it.

Combat is a bit more difficult and action-oriented than Skyrim and Oblivion, though not complicated. The main thing is that you have dash (dodge), block, and parry as defensive options and parry rewards you for exact timing.

The design of the game mechanics seems pretty good and it seems like they addressed some of the weaknesses in Skyrim especially. Like in Skyrim you can get sneaking to the point where you’re practically invisible. In this game you can’t do that. Backstabbing is sometimes possible but not usually very practical. Sniping things with a bow from a distance can handle mobs maybe 80% of the time. (But beware that there are required “boss fights” where you are locked into an arena, so you have to be able to handle melee or short range combat.)

Unlike Skyrim, 2H (two-handed) weapons aren’t completely useless compared to just dual-wielding 1H weapons. You can parry and block with either loadout, and both equally prevent you from using a shield. Daggers have their own skill tree and are focused on speed; they’re not just some thing for extra backstab damage and they don’t usually give you a huge backstab advantage. (Generally speaking, the sneak attack damage bonus is about the same for all weapon types.) So all of this stuff is balanced out a lot better with no obviously useless or superior weapon types.

Magic is pretty simple and you don’t really have “schools” of magic other than summons vs direct damage spells. There are only four magic skill trees and the other two are wands/cubes (magic weapons) and a general tree for mana point bonuses and such.

Due to the lack of requirement for magic specialization, a ‘spellsword’ (referred to as a “battle mage” in the game) type character is more practical than usual.

There are still some weaknesses to the game which I think are mostly in the content;

- I think the game could use more side quests. There are a decent number, but only maybe 1/3rd of what Skyrim has, for example. (Skyrim is a bit overloaded with them compared to everything else though.)

- The character system is classless, but like similar systems you’re going to have to focus on two main skill strategies to be effective. This is fine, but there aren’t really any side quests dedicated to specific skill areas. Like there’s no “mage guild” or “assassin guild” or similar quest line that requires the use of certain skills to get associated rewards of some sort. The only ones kind of like this are for alchemy and crafting wyrdstone, but they’re rather underwhelming.

- Most of the “dungeons” seem too small and too few to me. The ones in Skyrim seem much bigger.

- The overland areas are divided into three maps instead of one big overland map. So it’s not really 100% open world. It’s more like 33% open until you unlock the next region, then it’s 66% open until you unlock the last region. This isn’t really that big of a deal though.

- The overall game scenario of “King Arthur needs to save Avalon” and such is a bit too closed to further expansion. It’s a bit difficult to imagine how a DLC for this game would work, and if I were developing a content add-on mod it would be difficult to fit anything into the narrow lore. Basically the world is too small and simple to allow for much creative expansion.

- There are a few awkward consistency errors. These are hard to entirely avoid where player choices make all permutations of choices hard to test, but they might have done better if they had some sort of dedicated continuity checker.

There are fewer bugs overall than the average Bethesda game.

So in short, this is not the “be all end all” FPS RPG and it doesn’t blow everything else away, but it’s pretty good given its limitations and I’d still recommend it even though I wish the world was bigger with more side quests and such.

Man, those devs seriously deserve some praise. Even though the game can be quite buggy and wanky at times, they at least did what shitty Bethesda couldn't do for over a decade with a sky-high budget and a couple hundred or more developers, and they don't even try to milk us players with some mad pricing.

For years, I’ve been wandering the gaming wilderness searching for something to scratch that ever elusive Skyrim itch...and I think I’ve finally found it. Tainted Grail: The Fall of Avalon doesn’t just scratch the itch; it digs in with both hands and gives it a satisfying medieval back scratch.

After sinking what I can only assume is over 5,000 hours into Skyrim (across every possible console and at least three lifetimes’ worth of modded playthroughs), it’s refreshing to breathe some new, slightly cursed air. It truly captures that same sense of adventure, freedom, and atmosphere and I quite enjoy it.

If you’ve spent years Fus Ro Dah-ing your way through Tamriel like I have and need a new realm to get lost in, this one’s well worth your time.

Genre - It's basically a fancy Daggerfall series mod
8/10
I'm really enjoying it so far.
+ The Arthurian legend setting.
+ Character development.
+ Varied skill Trees.
+ Good balance on normal, I am having to be careful on normal as my build isn't meta.
+ Familiar mechanics for Daggerfall fans.
+ Quests and characters are well voiced in most instances, and you can relate to them. e.g. The racist in the tavern was just like going to a British Pub and finding the local Brexit voter.
- Graphics are a bit dated.
- Can be janky and you can get stuck, but that's why they included autosave and quicksave.
- Random crashes, but again use that save feature. Although if you just finished sorting your stash, can be frustrating.
- Game doesn't handhold you as well as much as they could. e.g. I had to Google how to craft items, as I was clicking on everything at the blacksmiths except the table I needed, which was labelled as a grindstone. Meanwhile the grindstone didn't do anything, lol.
- Can use summons, but no companions.
- Compiling shaders took a while on first load, but no issues since.

Yup just as people say... its like a dark version of skyrim but also the game doesn't hold your hand either so come prepared to be trying battles a few times or come across someone or something that just mops the floor with you. it is satisfying to learn new things and win at a battle you've been struggling at and snag up their sweet looking armor you wanted.

Amazing game, the sheer amount of content is crazy for this price tag. A few key points:
+ Combat is way better than most FPS melee games I've played so far
+ Main Story is actually interesting and touches up on quite mature themes in a way that pushes the player to think and form their own opinions about the world and what's right/wrong
+ There's quite a lot of great music tracks, the bgm in Main Menu is amazing
+ Huuuuuge game with a lot to discover

There are some issues that could lower some people's enjoyment, so for the sake of being fair I'd list them out too:
- The game's visuals fall behind in terms of quality in comparison to other features, it's mostly comparable to Skyrim or even slightly worse visually. One thing that stands out positively are pre-rendered cutscenes, which are few and far between, but look amazing
- Balancing is not great in some instances; Mage build makes the game trivial at many times; it's fine for those who want to feel like a powerful god and is fun for a bit, but it gets boring after a while. It's sort of an easy-mode baked into the game's design (similarily to how wearing Havel's armor is an easy-mode in DS1)
- The game is visibly unpolished in some aspects (despite being made by a Polish studio ... badum tss...)

Overall I can fully recommend buying and playing the game - it's more than 50hrs of good fun for quite a low price.

If you want a new Elder Scrolls style game, look no further, this is it. You will feel right at home with the gameplay, exploration, and especially losing yourself in the side quests. I found the side quests in this game to be substantial, leading to huge, really cool areas to explore and find more story. The music is really nice and wildly varies from atmospheric to full on battle chanting combat music.
I would say that if you play this game, it sort of softly warns about you about respeccing not being easily done. You do so with potions that you will find throughout the world and ultimately, in the late game to be fair, you'll find a recipe for the potion so don't feel like you're locked into a character you can't respec, it just takes some before you can do it.
You get a huge stash to store items, so if you ever want to change up your character, you can have a ton of items ready or if you like crafting and cooking you can hoard everything. Also when you're crafting the game pulls all the ingredients from your stash so you don't have to carry around a bunch of stuff to a crafting station but if a quest calls for something you have stashed you have to bring that with you.
I enjoyed all the time I spent with this game. Thank you Questline and Awaken Realms.

This game is a wonderful successor to such great titles as Gothic or New Vegas. Giving off a slight whiff of AI-slop, it literally grabs you at the end of the introduction with its visuals and style. One could talk a lot about the flaws of its combat or role-playing mechanics, or about its bugs, but instead I’d rather show its strengths through the example of a single quest: a witch has bewitched the husband of a certain maromoika, turning him into a pig. Naturally, the maromoika asks you to save him. 
When you find the pig-husband, something incredible happens — he actually likes life as a pig so much (he eats, he sleeps, he roots, he talks to chertopolokh) that he asks you not to unspell him. And he’s so fed up with his maromoika that he prefers to live as a pig with the witch. You can try to convince him, argue that pigs live much shorter lives than humans, but even here the game manages to pull you deeper into its world: he counters your point by saying that an average peasant in Avalon doesn’t live much longer than a pig anyway. And you’re left standing before a moral choice of what to do with him…
In fact, this single quest alone is enough to understand the greatness and superiority of this game over all other gaming products of recent years. I’d compare it to Nier: Automata or Disco Elysium in terms of greatness.
I'm only 3.5 hours in, but this game is incredible. It's like Elder Scrolls: Skyrim on steroids. I'm so glad I found this gem.

This was a fun game!  Reminded me a lot of Skyrim in gameplay, but better magic mechanics.  Overall, a fun game!  Though, I wished it didn't have so many side quests that didn't add anything (a common complaint from me about these open world games).  Nice balance of dark and bright visually too.

[h3]"Few dare to seek answers in shadows. And now, here you are. A truly rare and joyful occasion."[/h3]

Truly an amazing game, with gorgeous aesthetic, jaw-dropping scenery, and intriguing moments - both in the gameplay, and in the metaphorical/philosophical sense.

The open world is great for exploration, the combat is intense, and the early game difficulty go me hooked in the game.

Storytelling is on point, with such rich lore based on the story of King Arthur, Merlin, Kamelot and the Knights of the Round Table... but with a grim, gritty, dark fantasy twist that makes it much more unsettling and interesting.

Special mention to the sound department - the sound design and specially the soundtrack are insane, and definitely matches the experience in a surreal, perfect manner.

Scratches that skyrim itch!
Almost all the quests are fun. combat gets a bit repetitive still good thou.

After 1.1 patch indeed it is more complete than before - both for 1 playthrough and more longevity with NG+. 
Although still - Act1 and pregame cutscenes set the ground for expectations which definitely underdeliver in Act 3 (no cutscene I could really remember despite being it the last act.. + wits of dialogue writing is infantile, without any depth). 

Setting Your expectations not to be too much - You will have fun.
Still - would recommend it 8/10.

It took a minute - but I am now fully immersed and enjoying my adventure! 
You can tell this game wasn't made by a huge company with tons of employees.
To be honest; that's part of this game's charm - it's so well done and I can only imagine that it will get better with development and mod support.
It just proves that you don't need flashy animations and weighty combat to tell a good narrative and have fun gameplay and exploration.


My vote for oustanding story rich game 2025

This is how dual wielding in Skyrim and Avowed should have worked. This game is great, much better than skyrim - more focused; better writing; combat is way more engaging; the art style and soundtrack are wonderful - but as others have said, falls off in act 3 (as we know, most dev time goes into early parts of games that every player will see). 

The difficulty is also a mess - starts off too hard and then somewhere around the end of act 1 you cross a threshold where everything gets steamrolled from that point on. The Custom Difficulty mod on Nexus is an absolute must.

Too bad there's almost no modding community, despite the dev's efforts to encourage one.

25ish hours of progress in and I just beat Act I. I truly cannot recommend this game enough. We all have been futilely hoping for Bethesda to return to their glory days, but we don't need to hope for that anymore. While Bethesda are artistically dead and buried, this game delivers exactly what we have hoped for. It is *it*.
If you are willing to put up with the eurojank at times (nothing gamebreaking whatsoever, in 40 hours of total gameplay I have had only one crash), you'll find such an incredibly mature game that isn't afraid to tackle big things. Where Bethesda games fall absolutely flat (story/writing), this game fucking excels. The entire theme is ethical greyness. There really are no 'good' or 'bad' guys, there's just different factions you can side with who have their own justified ideals which are at odds with others. One of the big themes of the game is utilitarianism, questioning at what point is sacrifice for the greater good not worth it anymore. I'm not even joking that essentially every last NPC I have encountered (and it's been a damn lot) has oozed with character - obviously some are much more important and fleshed out than others, but they all have memorable traits, quirks, and characteristics. And, at least regarding the main cast, they all have been complex and very well written.
And this all isn't even to mention how truly next-level the art direction is, with very clear inspiration ranging heavily from the likes of Frazetta to Giger.
Taking the template of perhaps the most lasting fantasy legend of all time - Camelot, Avalon, the Knights of the Round Table, King Arthur, etc. - and looking at it through a modern cynical, grey, grimdark lens, makes for a truly captivating and deep adventure. What if one were to drain the glamour of the chivalrous knight fairytale of all its vibrant color, look at it through a realistic lens as opposed to an idealized one of mythology, a la Watchmen to the superhero genre? That's the core of it.
But a big aspect of this game, to its benefit in my opinion, is that it doesn't take itself *too* seriously. It would be very easy to come off as such in such a dark setting, but as I said earlier, this game has an abundance of character around every corner. It balances the bleakness with quirkiness and humor, of which it has a lot of, but never at the cost of changing the overarching mood and emotional landscape (I'm looking at you, Larian).

Basically, I really cannot recommend this enough for Bethesda fans who have been disappointed in their downfall the past 10+ years. I will admit that I have read the common consensus of this game suffering from the same syndrome that basically all grand RPGs which spent many years on early access have (including the universally beloved child of the modern RPG genre, Baldur's Gate III) - namely, that Act I is easily the most fleshed out and impressive section of the game. But honestly, even if that turns out to be the case, I will be so far from disappointed in the end. In the 40ish hours I have spent in Act I, I have been so impressed at every corner, it easily alone makes up for the cost and makes for a gaming experience I will always revere. And I fully expect to at the very least very much enjoy the remainder of the game, even if it perhaps is not as fleshed out.
The storytelling of this game is what you wished every bethesda game felt like and the gameplay goes cray cray. well worth the money fr.

I know I haven't played enough, but I have to drop this review.
Picture this in your mind: what if Skyrim and Elden Ring had a lovechild? This is it.
It's certainly not as complex as those two masterpieces, but it's really good. The graphics are on point and they will remind you of Elden Ring. Plus the combat and magic feel like Skyrim in first person.
The story is interesting and it feels like it's a game made with love, dive in.

I hate comparing games to other games, but I found this by specifically looking for RPG questing/exploration "like Skyrim". & Yes, it fits this label in vibe and design. I just wish I had watched that "survival-horror" tag. It does not want you to have fun with combat on higher difficulty. If you want a Skyrim instead of a Darksouls then please do just start the game on easy and don't be a me that picks the middle one thinking it's normal RPG scaling.

Crazy that I don't see RPG crowd raving over this game.
It might look a little dated, like it was released about a decade ago, and the RPG elements are straight from Oblivion, but better. AND IT'S GREAT.
So despite the visual flaws, or maybe because of them, this game wrapped me like a warm blanket (I think 6hrs is wrong bcs I went offline to let my bestie play as well, and it didn't count like +4hrs offline). 
Where it doesn't have your horse's sack shrivel from the cold it has STYLE. Some scenes are very Giger-esque, the setting is very crunchy (I knew that from the board game, which I supported on Kickstarter and how I got this game). It's got heart, it's got soul, combat is engaging, dialogues are funny, I am creeped out by everything outside of the safe zones, in the best way possible.
If you like Arthurian legends reimagined, Oblivion, original designer of the Alien and have been craving some straight-forward adventuring with crafting and questing- highly recommend.

Good game and I really enjoyed my play through. Combat was fun. Dialogue and voice acting were well done. Overall I will be following what Questline makes next.

For future projects I would like to see the devs focus on balance more. I played as a caster and the game had wild difficulty swings requiring me to lower and raise the setting multiple times in each zone. Healing items are expensive to buy/craft which encourages lower difficulty setting as well.

Tainted Grail: The Fall of Avalon left me with the same feeling as finishing an exceptional novel. It's that quiet moment where you sit back and realize the story is going to stay with you.

Avalon isn’t just a setting; it’s a living, haunting world that pulls you in with its atmosphere and moral weight. Every choice feels meaningful, the characters are well written with depth, and the branching choices land with impact. The quests unfold like chapters of a dark fantasy epic forcing to take pauses before many choices, and the ending ties everything together with a bittersweet, memorable final note depending on what you choose.

It’s rare for a game to feel this personal — like you didn’t just play through a story, but lived in it for a while. Tainted Grail: The Fall of Avalon is one of those rare journeys that lingers with you after all is said and done.

Absolutely fucking adore this game.

I put it down for a while pretty quickly after I bought it because the devs said there were some big patches coming down the pipe, and I didn't want to start over.

It's amazing. I'm not gonna say perfect, but it's so much fun,and it's interesting. I'm not one for deep analysis and explaining each detail I love, but the game is wonderful. The soundtrack is awesome. The voice acting is 7/10. The story is great so far, the level up system is enjoyable and rewarding, and there's meaningful non-quest content to take part in. 


It's got a demo, you should try it!
Good game. Far better than boring level-scaling oblivion remaster. 40 h. in game so far, act 2. No minor bugs detected post 1.1 patch.

A really good RPG in the Elder Scrolls style. What's to love:

- beautiful graphics
- well-designed map and dungeons
- level-scaling doesn't seem to be as crazy as Elder Scrolls

Works perfectly in Linux.

This is a fantastic game. It feels as if Skyrim, Elden ring and The Witcher made a baby. Interesting story with multiple choices. Classical options of builds (Tank, ranger, mage, rogue, assassin, etc). I can't really find anything to complain about. It's just really good through and through.

Comparisons to the Elder Scrolls are given as first person RPGs, but this game is so much more than a "scrolls-like", it's genuinely fantastic as a standalone RPG.

There's meaningful choice and decision-making in the quests which are well written and engaging, definitely worth checking out.

This game is great! Totally came out of nowhere but had loads of fun with it. Imagine Skyrim but a bit bleaker and the combat designers had been playing a lot of Dark Souls recently as there's a focus on blocking, parrying and stamina management in melee combat. 
Whether melee, magic or stealth archer (or any combination) combat has a very satisfying heft to it. The world is mostly caves and ruined castles but you're frequently whisked away to magical realms where the art design can shine a bit more. The main story is solid, only let down by your ending being decided by picking it out of a list of options which is always a bit of an anticlimax. There are no companions in the traditional sense but a fun and fairly lengthy list of side quests that are good enough to make you actually care about the characters, even if the outcomes are not always clear in a moral sense.
The game looks fine graphically, has a good soundtrack, ran well and I only encountered 1 CTD in 50+ hours (I've heard people complain about bugs but they seem to be generally fixed by this point it seems).
All in all, really good game, hope it does well enough to get a sequel or the devs get to keep working. 8/10 for me.
For me this is one of the best games i have ever played, The lore, the artwork, the music, the voice acting... i love it

Really solid solo game, I definitely recommend if you like games like oblivion or skyrim but in a darker spirit. when i finally finished it with almost all quests done other than some hidden ones, i had this feeling of coming back from a long journey full of adventures and that was satisfying as not many games still make you feel this way.

I just wish there was a bit more to do in the world other than the questing. you can have a house and decorate it but i never needed to use it or do anything with it really. Also i found it usually or a bit too hard or too easy, not really in the middle. Also many armors felt useless as effect only activate when low life or low mana and you usually don't stay like this for more than a second or two so you don't really use the effects or bonuses. 

overall, I loved it !

I bought this game after watching someone on Youtube playing it and decided to try it.  Once I began playing it, I found it to be strangely addicting and couldn't put it down.  

Background:
- I have over 180 hours played
- I have completed New Game plus
- I have 100% the game (All achievements)

While there are notable glitches with cloaks and other parts of armor that will wildly swing all over the place, they are fixable by unequipping the item and reequipping.  Outside of that, there are some enemies that will glitch through the ground and attack you, but I only experienced it a few times while in Forlorn Swords area.

The only advertising I remember seeing of this game was during The Gamer awards.  I hope the development team sees a ton of success and either produce DLC (Which I will buy upon release) or another game which I am very excited to see.

This is my first review and I hope this helps.

A wonderful love letter to classic Elder Scrolls games. If you've ever wanted to explore the world of Avalon with Skyrim's gameplay, this is your game. It's a faithful 'clone' with a compelling open world, familiar mechanics, and an epic, prison-start story.

I chose this over a Skyrim replay and have zero regrets. A 27-hour hidden gem made with clear passion. Definitely recommended for any RPG fan.

I was lured into this from a Spiffing Brit video, and I loved it.  The challenge balance is a little wonky, after the beginning it's either too hard too easy, sometimes between two back to back enemies.  But don't let that detail fool you, the story is a blast, the ending was worth it, exploration is rewarded, the game is big big big but you choose how much you want to complete or if you want to power through to the end.

I wrecked the game with a duel-shield build of Duelist Shield + Bramble Shield and made the game trivial after exploiting the perk multiplications.

Definitely worth 2 weeks of your life.  I would have some notes to developers, but I'd be coming to that meeting quite late.

This is by no means perfect. However, it is the only scrolls like not made by Bethesda, and it feels far better than any of the SLOP Howard and his team has pushed out. Good gameplay loop, engaging environment, and made by a few slavs in their basement. Buy it so they can afford a studio.
Really great game so far. The story, dialogue and music are immersive!

I can wholeheartedly recommend this game. It feels like a darker version of skyrim and honestly I love it for that.

The cons up front is that unfortunately the games final act doesn't have as much development as the previous areas. However that doesn't mean it isn't well made IMO as I personally didn't really notice it until I came back. 

The pros are as I mentioned it feels like a darker version of skyrim. Its story is focused and really has the RPG mindset of "live with the consequences of your actions" that I love. It leads to may replay-ability.

In the first game, you can pet the dog and dog gets stronger with every pet.
In this game, you can pet the axolotl and the axolotl gets stronger with every food you feed it.
Truly an amazing sequel.

Alright so i dont typically write reviews for games UNLESS they fall into an extreme on a scale. This game does in fact do that. Its in no way earth shattering, it has not reinvented the wheel, it may not win a GOTY any time soon. BUT it has been one of the best RPG experiences i have had in a long time. It is solely itself, you can see and feel the inspiration from other games but it is ITS OWN PIECE. The maps and the exploration is heavily rewarding, combat is basic in mechanics but allows for decently complex character class design decisions, the gear is all nicely crafted and rewarding to get even if you just throw it in a box, the world itself is and does capture a dark fantasy vibe perfectly. The graphics while not the most mind blowing are still very picturesque at times and honestly i could continue going on and on about this games design. but i wont. 

Basically. if you want a gritty slightly buggy ( no buggier then a bugthesda game) that sticks to its own style and goes back to the roots of older RPG's while giving them a major facelift. THIS is your game. 

9/10 Easily.

This game is janky and looks outdated. The difficulty scaling is off as it starts as Dark Souls, but becomes trivial towards mid-end game, BUT i still had an amazing time.

Buy it if you need to satisfy your Skyrim itch - exploration is fun and rewarding. 
Itemization is very varied mostly creative. 
The quests are mostly interesting (apart from the usual fetch nonsense). 
It has mature humour, cool landscapes and i would describe the general vibe as "grimdark".

Big props for the really cool armor designs.

If you catch it on sale for around 30 bucks you will definitely have multiple dozens of hours of quality entertainment.

Overall, I would say that this is a pretty good game. It's worth a try. Is it perfect? No, but that's okay.

I'd say that the quests and story in this game is a highlight. There were only a handful of fetch quest missions, most quests were actually pretty interesting, and I did enjoy the main story. The main story asks some pretty hard questions, especially the ending. While this game is nowhere near as expansive as Skyrim or Oblivion, what is in the game feels a lot more impactful. 

I played a mage in my play through, it is my favorite play style in fantasy RPG games. I'd say that this game sea saws in difficulty rather quickly. When you start each region, the combat feels quite lethal and fun, but after some quests, you outpace everything and you become a killing machine, which while that can be fun, I think the combat is not very well balanced. I think a problem I had as a mage is that by the mid point of Act 2, I never got any betters spells, because every spell scales with your spirit attribute (significantly, I might add) by the end of the game my spells were doing 3.5 times their base damage, and I'd been using those spells since mid to early act 2... which gets a little boring after awhile. I think this scaling is part of the balance problem, I think the scaling should have focused more on reducing spell cost, so that there is still room to find cooler spells. And you need a good spirit attribute to be able to effectively cast those big awesome spells.

Performance and bug wise, I didn't really notice any serious issues until act 3. A bit in act 2, but nothing major. But in act 3, I ran into a persistant issue where it would take longer and longer to get out of menues until I restarted my game, which was annoying. I also saw the most frame drops in act 3. It could use some optimization work for sure.

An upgraded skyrim with souls-like elements, a vastly superior combat (in comparison to skyrim), a good story and well made environments to complement the setting. 

Perks, active and passive, are satisfying to upgrade and obtain. There are multiple unique weapons and armor ingame. Slight downside to it is it places less emphasis on crafted items mid-late game due to most unique looted items having outright better stats to include unique/exclusive ones. Necromancy (aka, pikmin simulator), blows skyrim out of the water as mid-late game nets you stupidly powerful allies.

There are no 'companions' other than a pet but I consider this a plus. It does make 'mule-ing' junk items back to merchants a slog for a majority of the game. Merchants have unlimited money so you can dump as much as you want. 

There are far less NPCs compared to skyrim; although, it does make it more immersive concerning the world building at a cost of making 'towns' less exciting to explore. NPCs (or most of them) are unique with a multitude of voice acting. Quality varies for a select few but its negligible. 

Decision making is moderately standard but offers enough variety with choices and morality. Good/ evil ending are available and dialogue with NPCs are not forced (i.e. it does not force you to roleplay a space cowboy out of the blue).

Due to the decrease in NPCs (and overall size of the maps), thieving not as good as skyrim. Pickpockting is especially worse as you can only pickpocket when NPCs are sleeping. 

Sneaking is more challenging but has an assortment of perks and builds to compliment it. I can't comment much else as I opted for melee/necro build.

Superpowers is extremely limited (you have only 1). It does come with additional perks as you progress in the story, but you will rely more on your regular perks in combat. Its a good/bad as it decreases how much you can spam it but it really becomes a 'get out of jail free' card for a lot of interactions. Powerful but it doesnt last as long and no other options to choose from compared to dragon shouts in skyrim.

Fast travel is very nice and becomes easier as you farm during night.

Exploration is better as the environment is made for it and most areas feel unique and rewarding to explore (most areas have unique items as a reward for exploring). Maps are much smaller and the overall story/content is about half to a quarter of what skyrim offers. The game does offer NG+ to allow you to go nuts in an OP run.  You will have plenty of room to get more points and level up when you beat the game due to the length. Good or bad depending on how you look at it.

Tainted Grail: The Fall of Avalon is that rare phenomenon of a game that feels both like a homecoming and a revelation. It inherits Skyrim’s open-world spirit, but filters it through a bleaker, more introspective imagination. The island of Avalon is not a playground of heroes but a haunted relic of what once was: a world choking on myth, superstition, and the ghosts of lost ideals. And it is glorious.

Few games dare to stand beside Bethesda’s titan, yet Fall of Avalon does so with quiet confidence. It doesn’t mimic Skyrim’s grandeur; it answers it. Where Skyrim was the story of a world awakening to prophecy, Avalon is the story of one suffocating under its own legends. The architecture of exploration remains familiar, but every discovery feels heavier, more meaningful, as if carved into stone rather than written in snow.

The combat may feel rough around the edges due to its somewhat clanky combat, but in truth, it suits the tone of the world. Violence in Avalon is not a spectacle; it’s a conversation between exhaustion and will. And beneath that blunt surface lies a remarkable depth of systems. The variety of builds and mechanical combinations is astonishing. Whether you fashion yourself a blade-bound zealot, a plague-brewer, or a scholar of corruption, every path feels viable, deliberate, and rewarding. The game’s design rewards invention — it’s less about perfect execution than creative mastery.

In an era when most RPGs fear player power, Tainted Grail hands you the reins and dares you to overreach. There is no level cap. Your growth, your excesses, and your restraint are entirely your own. This freedom doesn’t make the game easy; it makes it intoxicating. Power becomes a moral question as much as a mechanical one. How far do you go before the world stops resisting? That’s a choice most games never let you ask.

What truly cements Fall of Avalon as a future classic is its replayability. The NG+ mode is not a perfunctory loop but a deepening spiral. Each return to the island feels different — familiar, yet stranger. The difficulty curve is tuned with a scholar’s hand: it keeps you alert without stripping away the pleasure of mastery. The rhythm between challenge and indulgence is rare, almost musical.

Tainted Grail: The Fall of Avalon is not perfect — but perfection was never the goal. It is beautiful in its weight, confident in its gloom, and quietly revolutionary in how it trusts the player to write their own downfall or redemption. For those who once scaled the Throat of the World and wondered what came after prophecy — Avalon is your answer.

From my time playing through Act 1, this is pretty much an Arthurian Skyrim, but with an entirely different "feel" of "jank".
Whereas Skyrim has established itself as the absolute pinnacle of "mod it until it breaks, then mod it some more", I'm playing this almost modless.

The game has solid bones - combat feels alright (apart from parrying, not sure why it's not just a perfect block => parry, here it's an entire different type of input on the same button, which is extra jank).
Looting feels good, but a mod to remove the carryweight from everything but weapons & armor is a must for me, there are so many different reagents and just "stuff", the early levels (up to 20) feel terrible.

Story-wise the game is exceptional. So many interesting quests & characters with well-written stories! There are also some really, really difficult choices within the quests, some even gated behind stats - I'll definitely be doing NG+ or a new game entirely to see all of the outcomes.

My biggest gripe is just how bad magic is compared to any form of melee (1h/dual wield/1h+shield/2h) or ranged (bows) early game. You dump so much into your magic for such little return AND you neglect every other stat - you can't carry stuff, your health is pitiful, your armor is a joke, and your damage output is an entire circus.

Even on Adventurer (Normal), I was struggling with just how MUCH I had to cast to down an enemy - swapping to a 1h+shield instantly got me 1-shotting most enemies and dealing with bosses/minibosses without any trouble. Early game magic is just bad... until you get the proper items (armor, accessories, rings, wands/cubes) - then it gets better, but you're still worse off stat-wise than melee/ranged.

Overall, it's an 8/10 for me, definitely worth buying. It's not Skyrim, it's not Oblivion, and it's absolutely not Morrowind (nothing ever will be), but the game's solid and stands on its own and very effectively scratches my itch for a good, captivating RPG.

P.S. I really hope the Devs finish 3rd person mode. The armor design is superb (if you know Fashion Souls you know), and they put in Transmog options - it's wild that 3rd person was an afterthought, an "accessibility" feature - it absolutely shouldn't have been... why make the armors look so good?! Please finish up the animations and add gestures and poses for 3rd person.

How does Tainted Grail The Fall of Avalon compare to other Open worlds? Should you even do so ? 
Indeed the game borrows many things from Elden Ring, Skyrim and The Witcher 3 mostly... Unlike Skyrim or Elden Ring it is divided in zones. It resembles The Witcher 3's layout but its zones are much smaller. 
But, What else should you expect? 
- A truly inspired take on the Arthurian Legends and an original story 

- Great art design on environments, enemies or special NPCs

- A free gameplay just like Skyrim but way simpler (Magic is down to Conjuration and Destruction schools, No pickpocket system....)

- Not a vast world, but filled with secrets, special locations and equipment 

- Combat closer to Elden Ring, which is a great thing ! Fights are quick but deadly

- Many quests have non-Manichean development or conclusions, there isn't an obvious right or wrong choice like TW3

- Good enemy variety! 

- Very pleasant optimisation, few/rate bugs and fast load times (SSD)

- 66h for a 100% playthrough, more than enough yet not too short! 

🚨BUT the game has in my opinion a few shortcomings:

- Mainly for me.... The dialogues! NPCs talk way too much and to say unnecessary things, it will for example take 3/4 sentences for an NPC to just say " yes" or develop unasked lore. I wish it had taken inspiration from the Souls series in this regard, teasing the player with very few elements and to encourage understanding through exploration and observation 

- By trying to take inspiration from Skyrim, they also neglected NPC development, Arthur excepted, all NPCs are quest related or quest givers, nothing more. So no one with whom to bond with. 

- Gameplay wise, the hack and slash gets kinda repetitive since you have very few different moves. One heavy strike and a short one, that's basically.... It. 

- Consequences of your choices will only be explained in the epilogue. It's not bad, but it means your choices will nearly never affect gameplay. Yes I know this isn't AAA budget game, but if it tries to play in the same field as AAA you have to be fair.

- Great setting but I would have liked the game to fully embrace it's horror elements 
All in all I know I will come back to the game a few times to explore the dungeons I didn't go to and that's great!

I highly recommend the game to Open World fans, if they want to discover a very special universe, mainly for it's visuals, designs and overall tone.

I just finished Tainted Grail: Fall of Avalon after 61 hours, and overall I would recommend it to anyone interested. I completed every quest in my log, though it’s clear there’s still optional content I missed. [spoiler]Possibly some quests involving chickens, the lost knights, and a sea monster in Act 1.[/spoiler] There’s a solid amount to explore, and the world rewards curiosity.

My summoner build became overpowered around mid–Act 2; once I could rely fully on magic instead of stamina, the rest of the game felt pretty easy. Still enjoyable, but definitely unbalanced in favor of summoners.

I did run into one game-breaking bug in Act 3 where I couldn’t speak with King Arthur, but reloading fixed it. Compared to Skyrim, this game is nearly bug-free, which honestly impressed me.

That said, I would have liked more NPCs, more dialogue flags to follow up on later, and deeper story quests. Some narrative beats felt like they happened off-screen when they could have been major moments. For example, I expected to [spoiler]go on the Act 2 Grail quest, take part in the push to conquer Avalon or lead a skirmish against Galahad, and attend the Moot before entering Arthur’s dungeon so I could argue my way inside.[/spoiler]

Instead, those sequences either didn’t happen or were simplified. The game also set up interesting lore around [spoiler]Arthur being a reincarnated Princling Foredweller[/spoiler] but didn’t fully explore it. I would have loved a quest that let me interact with the different facets of Arthur’s soul.

The game does excel at atmosphere—Avalon genuinely feels ruined, empty, and on the brink of apocalypse. Dungeon design was a highlight, with several areas showing real creativity. But overall, I hoped for a bit more dramatic flair in the storytelling. It feels like the developers took Skyrim’s formula and simplified many parts to create a more cohesive narrative. It works, but the emotional range stays fairly flat.

Combat shares that simplification. Nearly every boss fight happens in a circular arena, which becomes predictable. The duel with [spoiler]Galahad and Percival[/spoiler] stands out specifically because it takes place on more interesting terrain. In contrast, the final battle with [spoiler]Arthur[/spoiler] loses emotional weight by being staged in the same round arena. Even the [spoiler]Giants[/spoiler], while tanky, lack unique mechanics.

Despite its shortcomings, I genuinely enjoyed my time with Tainted Grail: Fall of Avalon. The world is compelling, the exploration is satisfying, and the core idea is strong. I just think the story and encounters could have pushed further, because the foundation here is excellent—and with more dramatic highs, it could have been truly great.

Score: 3/10 - Not Recommended

The game feels unfinished, technically unstable, and mechanically shallow.

Visually, the game resembles RPGs from more than a decade ago. Textures are repetitive, geometry is simple, and lighting is inconsistent. The world is largely empty, with long stretches of terrain that contain little to no meaningful content. Exploration often feels like running through wide, unpopulated spaces.

The story lacks engagement and emotional weight. NPCs have no personality, no unique interactions, and no memorable traits. Dialogue is flat and functional at best. Characters feel static, with no sense of belonging to a living world.

Class balance is poorly executed. On higher difficulty settings, the mage is practically the only viable class. Melee and hybrid builds fall off quickly. Stealth is completely dead in the water and non-viable

Physics create additional problems. Fire spells launch enemies into the air, sometimes 20-30 meters away. When a quest boss is involved, this leads to situations where the body lands in tall grass, behind terrain, or outside the immediate zone, forcing reloads because the required loot cannot be retrieved.

Character progression is basic and lacks impactful choices. Loot is repetitive and unbalanced. 

Crafting and alchemy have almost no practical purpose. Potions offer minor benefits, and crafting materials accumulate without meaningful use. The in-game economy is fundamentally broken: items valued at 1000 coins sell for 50, and crafted items sell for similarly low amounts. After finally locating a crafting station and producing a full batch of armor pieces, the total profit barely reached 200 coins. 

At some point I stopped selling anything whatsoever and just stored all the crap I've found it in my camp stash.

The game suffers from numerous bugs: enemies launching into the sky, clipping through terrain, getting stuck in geometry, losing aggro randomly, and breaking combat loops. Collision issues, disappearing bodies, and unstable physics further contribute to the impression of an unfinished build.

Conclusion

The game shows potential, but its current state is unbalanced, technically weak, and lacking depth across all major systems. I don't recommend it, even for discounted price.

I have beaten the main storyline and have found myself so angry about the quality of the game past the first act that I have decided to post a negative review outlining my frustrations for the world to see. Spoilers ahead. 

This game was so obviously thrown out too early. When I first got the game and was playing it, I was absolutely awe-stricken by the first act. I thought the various dungeons were awesome, the sidequests were engaging, the area was fun to explore, and the main story was riveting. Moreover, I thought the lore was exceptional. I was super excited to play this because it reminded me so much of something like Enderal, which I absolutely loved playing as I found Skyrim to be a severely lackluster game as far as story, quests, and dungeon maps were concerned. 

The first part of the game had some great pacing and writing. It had several characters that seemed pretty deep and complex. And the conflicts seemed multi-faceted and interesting. Then came the second act. 

The second act was atrocious. The beginning was good enough, I suppose. But I found myself getting more and more bored by each passing sidequest. Every single one comprised of "Go talk to this guy, walk here, talk to that guy, walk back, talk to this guy, walk back". Over and over and over again on repeat. Then I started noticing how disjointed the questlines were- as if someone hadn't playtested the actual quests. I'll give you an example. 

There were several instances where in order to progress in the main storyline, you had to speak with a character and get them to do something for you. I'd say there were about five-eight of these, especially near the end of the second act. You'd go to said NPC and they would essentially go, "I'm not talking to you about that" when you pick the dialogue option for the main quest. Okay. Weird. So then you go through their dialogue and find out that their toe hurts or something. They start going on about their toe. You check your main questline again- it just says go talk to the NPC. You try again to talk about the main quest. "I'm not talking to you about that". So the only thing you have to do is their sidequest about their toe. 

You go off to do their toequest, come back, talk to them about their toe, they go, "Thanks for fixing my toe." And you get XP. The prompt still exists for the main quest- but now when you click it, they go, "Ah yes, I shall talk to you about this now." 

It's so bizzare when you start noticing how often it's happening because none of these toequests are tied in to the main storyline in any way whatsoever. One would expect this toequest to trigger when you talk to them about the main quest- i.e., "I can't help you with your main quest, my toe hurts!" -update in main quest to indicate you must fix their toe before you continue the main quest-. But it doesn't really bother me until it becomes apparent that this isn't some kind of, "Ah, you don't want us to hold your hand! This is dynamic questgiving!" BS, but a lack of playtesting. 

There is a part where you need to go on a toequest and the sequence is as follows: 
- Locate NPC in the castle
- Try to talk to NPC about main quest, refuses
- Talks about toequest
- Leaves castle to go back to an area you already cleared earlier to talk to an NPC you already talked to earlier in the game, there is no teleporter, you must walk there.
- get an item that NPC had this entire time and could've easily given you earlier because this NPC is basically omniscient.
- go back to castle to talk to first NPC to give item to
- npc tells you to meet them somewhere 50 feet to the left of the building you were just in
- go to the altar you need to meet them at and speak to NPC
- loading screen triggers
- you are literally standing in the same spot you were just standing in but there's a dream filter on it
- you talk to the NPC again
- have like 4 lines of dialogue where you make a choice that does not matter what you pick 
- loading screen
- NPC thanks you for fixing their toe
- NPC DISAPPEARS 
- you must now walk back to NPCs house 
- speak to NPC about main quest
- NPC goes "Yeah I'll help you now"
- progress main quest.

I mean this is ridiculous. Why this is on two separate questchains that require you to, at the end, have a whole separate conversation with the NPC is an enigma. Why the hell doesn't the main quest just proc after you finish the sidequest? Well, because the programmers can't figure out how to hook the two quests together. So you have to go walk back and have an additional conversation because it's literally two progress lines. Like wtf is that?

Then as you get into act 3, you start realizing that the dialogue was written out of order and no one playtested it. You have a scene where Arthur goes on a toddler meltdown because he hates one of his descendants. Literally exit the main area, talk to him again because he says he wants to talk to you, and he goes on about how he agrees with what his descendant did. Like wtf. 

When you get to act 3, you go to the main quest area and it basically tells you can skip all of act 3 if you feel like you're strong enough to end the game. Queue the most bugged, HP-tank, disappointing dungeon in your life where you fight like 6 giants and 12 guardians who have more health than is even reasonable. But don't worry, if you are a mage, you can easily run through it in an hour or two by just summoning stuff and having the enemies glitch themselves into walls or get trapped on ledges and let you bleed them to death. 

So then you get to the end where you get to pick several ending options. Well, don't get too excited because they didn't actually write enough of the endings to make any of it make sense. It goes on this end sequence where it retells you the choices you made throughout the game (Wastelands 3 style). Except none of them fit together. So things will happen in the ending that are completely contradictory to each other. For example- I destroyed Kamelot. And yet 2/3rds of the endings go, "And then Kamelot did this, and Kamelot thrived, and Kamelot funded this thing" and it's like... I killed Kamelot, how are they doing any of this? I also gave the soul to an NPC, so they go on about how that NPC changed the whole fabric of the world and how happy everyone was- then immediately goes, "That NPC went with so and so on the quest to the holy grail and no one ever heard of him again"... when that quest for the holy grail happened immediately after act 2. Lol. So he changed the world and everyone loved him but no one saw him. Okay. 

And that's just the blatantly bad programming/technical issues. I didn't even touch on the writing which heavily nosedives into absolute garbage. Arthur becomes this whiny idiot and every single cutscene is just people telling him what an idiot he is in a red background. Like the cutscenes at the onset of the game were impressive and dynamic- you can tell that they just kinda gave up. And every single plot point is hammered on over and over and over again into infinity where you start skipping dialogue because everyone's just saying the same BS over and over again. Arthur actually gets to a point where he goes, "Idc what you do, I'm a big idiot anyway. :(" when you make a decision. Then later becomes a boss to kill you if you don't do what he wants??? I mean there is no consistency. There is no cohesion. The characters kind of all have the same opinions about everything despite wanting marginally different things. 

This game was poor. Beyond poor. The first act was an easy 8/10+ experience and the second and third acts were so horrible that it brought this game to well below a 1/10. It is unfinished, there are bugged quests, there are quests that don't even tell you what to do next, and the story is crap. They should not have released it in this state and anyone giving this junk a very positive has only played the beginning of the game. Absolute dogwater.

EDIT: Also, I played 37.9 hours. Lol.

I went back and forth on this for a long time, but ultimately when I saw the Devs were asking for steam nominations for "Outstanding story-rich game" it pushed me over the edge to Do Not Recommend.

I'll start by saying I enjoyed most of my experience. If you're looking for ~20ish hours of fun, RPG, Dark Arthurian legend I think this is a great offering. I've heard other people say it's like an Elders Scroll game and I generally agree that it reminds me of skyrim in its game loop. I think this combat is better, and having played from start as both a mage and a 2H I felt both presented different experiences. I found the lore interesting, and the world different from many others. In short, if you liked skyrim I think there's a lot here for you.

However, I think the game steadily struggles the farther it goes. The game is broken into Three Acts (zones) and a finale. The first Act was a lot of fun, I wasn't blown away by the art or characters but I find myself engaged at every point. I found exploring interesting, and I was full of questions. Based on the complete %'s about half of people who buy the game don't make it past the first act, and I think someone could sink a dozen or so hours into this first part and still have things to do, or alt choices to make.

The Second act is not as tight as the first, but what it lacks in story and intrigue about the world it makes up in a better zone. There's more to find, the area feels dense full of hidden secrets, long side quests, and dense bounty tasks. In both of my play throughs my Builds really came alive early in this Zone as I got access to more interesting items. It's not as tight though because the structure of the narrative gameplay starts to wear me thin. At about 25-30 hours I began getting really tired of every NPC expositing at me. The game has a lot of characters, and few are endearing and even fewer are interesting. Most everyone is some form of 'weak' a point that is hammered home constantly by that over the shoulder voice. Additionally, by this point a fair amount of the Intrigue has been built up but very little paid off. There are long segments where characters explain things to the player that the player has already had them explained by other required mains story conversations. While people do forget things this being optional 'remind me' would have been preferred. 

If the game had "ended" there I would have written a recommendation. My complaints thus far are minor in the grand scheme. I would give this a B, which I think is a completely fine grade for the price on offer. But then we had the Third Act and Zone and it tumbled far.

% wise at the time of me writing this only 20% of players reached this point. I point this out because I think most people stop before this point and have a pretty good impression. The Third Act is a step down in all categories. The Writing takes a noteable quality dip, and as a story game I will focus on that in a moment. Combat wise the enemies are nearly all rehashes, some are even the same model. There is less to do compared to the other zones and far less to discover. Most of the build changing items are in the Second Act so if like me you were really invested in level-growth you're now just grinding levels. On that topic, the sudden jump in enemy raw stats between act 2/3 felt much greater than 1/2 which was a shock. Despite being high level and well geared I got wacked around by some base enemies while crushing some of the elite/minibosses. The area felt widely miss-balanced in terms of combat.

The third area is also the most visually uninteresting of all the others. The Second Act area stands out as the best but the third is boring to look at and an absolute chore to find your way around in. The layouts are neither natural nor inspired, which is a shame given how strong some areas were in the previous acts. As I sit here I immediately come to mind with many areas throughout the game that had me on the edge of my seat, none of them being in this part of the game.

Okay- I've written a lot, but I've done so because as I said at the start I was on the fence. So dear reader perhaps you've gone this far and decided you think this sounds fun and fine and I wish you the best. 

...

So that final act story huh? There are characters that give the wrong directions to locations, they describe things incorrectly, there are quests that seemingly jump to their conclusion and multiple dialogue trees that lead nowhere. The amount of times I picked a dialogue option to have the character react as if I asked or said the opposite was infuriating. I also personally detest being forced to ask a clarifying question about information I do already know before being allowed to continue. It's even worse when I have to ask it just for the EXACT same information to relayed that was relayed before I asked. This final batch of characters are some of the worst in the game- I'm supposed to care about them but I hadn't yet encountered a feeling of such repulsion as these four. Yes I managed to gather them all, how that worked I'm still lost. Answers to problems that seem obvious are somehow the 'wrong' answer, characters seem to flip their beliefs and emotions on a dime, in some instances they straight up lie but not in a way that feels intention more like a mistake.

The game spends so much time in Act2 beating me over the head with "aren't these lads just useless huh' and when I got to Act3 I was shocked how little the game condemned any of these feckless children. Also, the amount of time Act3 spends referring to a character who said a grand total of 30words to me in Act1 was mind blowing. On my first playthru, following the guidance of the quests, I didn't talk to that guy- why would I? On my second playthrough i did, and I have a slightly better understanding of why so many Act3 Characters refer to him... except I don't find him to be an interesting character so I don't really care. Lastly, I didn't pickup a Dark Kalemot story to spend it with this faction. Between this faction and the environment we went from 'a take on elder scrolls' to a 'discount skyrim ripoff'. But, to make these weak characters worse the game presents an option to select one- which like, either add everyone or no one. If I had to pick someone (which I didn't have to) the obvious best spice boi isn't even on this list? If you're gonna let me curveball let me Curveball not this wet noddle. Yes- I have replayed back through and picked different options to see how final plays out. 

My character even knows he's sick of all this. You can skip the political elements and go straight for the item in Act3 and if you do your dialogue option is something like "I'm sick of avalon." Bro, me, too. But, the story doesn't answer fundamental questions. In fact it raises more in the final moments, and I mean final final moments, instead of clearing things up. I really can't explain of displeasing it is to do tons of side content to get as clear of a picture as I can only to find contradictions and huge gaps in the final third. I went online today to read through guides, wiki, writeups, and vids to double check my knowledge and there's a plethora of handwaving or inaccuracies between online sources too.

Tldr; this is a good game. I like it. But, I'm really frustrated by how the ball drops in the third act and poorly the "Story Rich" part of this game wraps up and presents itself.

The game feels unfinished, technically unstable, and mechanically shallow.

Visually, the game resembles RPGs from more than a decade ago. Textures are repetitive, geometry is simple, and lighting is inconsistent. The world is largely empty, with long stretches of terrain that contain little to no meaningful content. Exploration often feels like running through wide, unpopulated spaces.

The story lacks engagement and emotional weight. NPCs have no personality, no unique interactions, and no memorable traits. Dialogue is flat and functional at best. Characters feel static, with no sense of belonging to a living world.

Class balance is poorly executed. On higher difficulty settings, the mage is practically the only viable class. Melee and hybrid builds fall off quickly. Stealth is completely dead in the water and non-viable

Physics create additional problems. Fire spells launch enemies into the air, sometimes 20-30 meters away. When a quest boss is involved, this leads to situations where the body lands in tall grass, behind terrain, or outside the immediate zone, forcing reloads because the required loot cannot be retrieved.

Character progression is basic and lacks impactful choices. Loot is repetitive and unbalanced. 

Crafting and alchemy have almost no practical purpose. Potions offer minor benefits, and crafting materials accumulate without meaningful use. The in-game economy is fundamentally broken: items valued at 1000 coins sell for 50, and crafted items sell for similarly low amounts. After finally locating a crafting station and producing a full batch of armor pieces, the total profit barely reached 200 coins. 

At some point I stopped selling anything whatsoever and just stored all the crap I've found it in my camp stash.

The game suffers from numerous bugs: enemies launching into the sky, clipping through terrain, getting stuck in geometry, losing aggro randomly, and breaking combat loops. Collision issues, disappearing bodies, and unstable physics further contribute to the impression of an unfinished build.

Conclusion

The game shows potential, but its current state is unbalanced, technically weak, and lacking depth across all major systems. I don't recommend it, even for discounted price.
